course.subject: CENG
course.name: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering
course.description: From chemistry to engineering, molecules to useful products. Physical, chemical and biochemical transformation of materials. Survey of industries related to modern chemical and biological engineering. Basic principles of materials and energy balance. Strategy of molecular synthesis, process selection and design, economic and environmental considerations. Examples taken from a diverse range of products spanning realms of food, consumer products, energy, environment, and medicine. Case studies and team projects on process and product design. For engineering students only.

reviews.author: seanlo
reviews.title: a good course for those who want to know more about CBE
reviews.comment_content:
This course contains three main topics
1. Conservation Laws and Material Balance
    Chapter 1 could be the easiest part of this course.
Only some simple concepts and a few formulas you must remember and understand. If you have learned chemistry in high school then it could be easy for you. But you must put some attention on controlling units.  
2. Balance, motion, and storage of Energy
    Things started to get more difficult since Chap.2.
Some fundamental knowledge about Thermal Dynamics could really help you on this chapter. The first law of Thermal Dynamics is the core of this chapter so you must remember its basic theorem and formulas. Keep an eye on UNITS !!
3. Transport and Kinetic
     Chapter 3 is mostly about the transport of first-order reactions and Pharmacokinetics. It could be the most complicated one in these three topics. Many formulas that you HAVE to remember and once you wanna realize it well you must know some calculus before. In addition to that, there could be some medical nouns and they might appear in your quiz and final.

Overall, you could learn something useful if you gotta take a CBE major or tend to know more about CBE. But if you really don't have any interest in the relative field, you must think more than twice before take it.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Chau is nice and willing to discuss with students or explain the detail of concepts to you after class. She would do every chalk-talk question step by step which is quite helpful for students to realize well. TAs are also nice and patient. Course PPTs are HELPFUL.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Ying Chau seems very passionate in her teaching and would give opportunities to ask questions anytime during class. However, professor tend to over complicate things resulting in a disconnect between her teaching and the students' understanding. You still learn some from her teaching but I needed to reinforce my understanding by going over the ppt slides again and asking TA.

However, I decided to give teaching an A because the format of the teaching mode in this course is somewhat unique compared to other courses in the university. Basically, the class is divided to ~10 groups of 4-5 people where students can sit together with their group mates during class with one TA assigned to each group. Every class there would be a chalk-talk question where students are supposed to figure out together with help of TA. Therefore, class would not get boring and is very much interactive.
reviews.comment_grading:
Chalk-talk presentation (15%)
During each workshop and studio, students in teams of 5 will work together to answer questions (given in advance) and teams are randomly picked to respond. One student (decided by the team) will present on behalf of the team in front of the class. Each team will be called at least 5 times, so there is no excuse about missing the opportunity to score. Note that each student will do chalk-talk presentation once. The presenting student will be graded on: thoroughness, logic, clarity

Quizzes (30%, 2 best out of 3)
An open-book, open-notes quiz will be given towards the end of each module. Each quiz will have 10 multiple-choice questions and you are to answer them individually. Your two best quizzes will be counted towards the course grade.

Studio write-ups (15%)
A 1-2 page write-up, with no particular format, as long as it is in your own words, to reflect on what you have learnt in the studio.

Final exam (40%)

Quizzes and Final are open-book but require understanding of the course material. Open-book still helps as there are still some formulas here and there but the exams ultimately tests the students' understanding.

reviews.comment_content:
The course is called Intro to Chemical and Biological engineering, but it's mostly just focused on physics and chemistry.

There's a good number of topics covered, but its not really that in-depth. If you have taken DSE chemistry and physics, most of the stuff is not going to be an issue.

The topics covered are:
1. introduction
2. role of chemical engineering
3. describing physical quantities
4. solving engineering problems
5. material balances
6. fluid flow
7. mass transfer
8. reaction kinetics
9. energy balance
10. process control
11. process economics
reviews.comment_teaching:
If it hadn't been for attendance taking during the lesson (using iPRS), I wouldn't have went to the classes.

Chau Ying's teaching is so bad the TAs do a far better job. You might get even more confused after taking her class, so the best option is to prepare for the classes beforehand (that is, if she decides to upload the lecture notes earlier. Sometimes, she only uploads the lecture notes less than an hour before the lesson.)

The 3 studios are essentially labs (in 3 or 4 ppl groups), with a worksheet that you have to hand in to be graded (pass/fail).

For the individual project, you are given some topics to choose from, and you would need to choose a product/problem related to that topic to do a presentation on.

The final is not that difficult. you won't use up all 3 hours for the 20 questions, and it's open book as well, so you can just print all the lecture notes.
reviews.comment_workload:
Other than the individual project, the general workload is quite light.

The homework is quite easy as long as you go through the materials from the tutorial sessions.
For the studio worksheets, you can probably do most of the questions before even attending the lab.

The individual project is what's going to take up most of your time. My advice is to allow yourself around a month to do it, so you can take your time to decide on a topic to write about.

- Module 3 Quiz

reviews.author: Luweegee
reviews.title: Moderate Content, High Workload
reviews.comment_content:
The course materials are generally interesting. The amount of content is alright as it doesn’t contain too much topics to be learnt. The course mainly focuses on three main modules and concepts, but the questions can get extremely difficult and tricky.

===Content=== (** = important concept & equations)
Module 1: Chemical Industry, Food Industry & Material Balance
• Production of High Fructose Corn Syrup
** Material Balance at steady state (In – Out + Production – Consumption = 0)

Module 2: Energy Industry & Energy Balance
• Energy types (Primary vs Secondary) & Energy units
• Forms of Energy (Internal, Kinetic, Potential, Work)
** Energy Balance in steady state
** Enthalpy & Internal Energy of ideal gas & incompressible liquids
** Energy change in reactions (Enthalpy change of reaction)

Module 3: Pharmaceutical Industry, Transport and Kinetics
• Types of drugs & Production
• Drug delivery
** Drug Kinetics (Differential equations & Material balance)
** Passive & Facilitated Diffusion

===General Comments===
This course can give you overall insights of chemical engineering, which involves a lot of material and energy balance. You can learn some equations to solve related problems. However, the content can get difficult as professor literally teaches Year 2 chemical engineering stuff and differential equations. The stuff you'll learn also isn't too useful in other engineering fields...

I think the content load is moderate as you just need to know the material and energy balance equations, and drug kinetics equation. The hardest part have to be the diffusion part in Module 3 as the concepts are very hard to understand, while material balance in Module 1 is the easiest since you apply the same equation again and again.

Professor generally loves to invite post-graduates to share their research field and guests speakers working in the chemical engineering field. They give a lot of insights to the industry, but it's kinda boring if you're not interested.
reviews.comment_teaching:
===Teaching===
She can explain concepts in clear way and show us how the formulas are deduced. She also explains the notation used to avoid confusion (like the use of brackets in energy balance)

She also demonstrates how the questions are done by writing it on paper and asks us if we have any questions after class through iPRS. She also held a review session for final exam.

The bad thing is that she sometimes expect us to have decent background information. She LOVES not giving important information or not telling us to make assumptions in homework, which can get really frustrating. She also didn't explain the diffusion part in Module 3 clearly and it's very easy to get confused.

===Lesson Atmosphere===
The lesson atmosphere is very relaxed :D Professor sometimes play music before lessons and during lessons (in short breaks). She'll make jokes and analogy during lessons and also invite students to come at the front for demonstration (of how diffusion works).
reviews.comment_grading:
The great thing is that YOU DON'T NEED TO MEMORIZE ANYTHING! All the quizzes and final exam are OPEN-BOOK!

You can get a good grade already if your score is above mean. I heard people saying you can get A- if your score is around 1 SD above mean but I'm not too sure... The mean for quizzes and final exam is generally low so if you do good, then you can get very high marks above the mean.

===Grading===
Class Participation - 5% (3% iPRS + 2% Peer Grading for Project)
Homework - 10%
Quizzes - 15% (Best 2 out of 3)
Project - 30%
Final Exam - 40%

===Statistics===
Quiz 1:  Mean - 6.3/10 ; SD - 1.93
Quiz 2:  Mean - 4.5/10 ; SD ??
Quiz 3:  Mean - 6.26/10
Project:  Mean - 73.1/100 ; Range: 0 ~ 95
Final:  Mean - 46.4/100 ; Range: 0 ~ 86

===My Scores===
Class Participation - 5/5
Homework - 8.08/10
Quizzes - 13.5/15 [Quiz 1 - 9/10 ; Quiz 2 - 9/10 ; Quiz 3 - 8.5/10]
Project - 25.81/30 [Raw Score: 86.03/100]
Final - 31.4/40 [Raw Score: 78.5/100]
-------
Final Score: 83.79
Final Grade: A

===Quizzes===
You'll have a quiz when the professor finishes one module. You got 30~40 minutes to complete the 10 marks paper. The difficulty is fine. The quizzes are OPEN-BOOK and OPEN-NOTES so you don't need to memorize anything :)

Be sure to do your best for the Module 1 quiz because that quiz is the easiest!

===Project===
Oh god the project is so freaking annoying. You need to pick a theme of your project in the given ones and present your team's solution to the problem you've picked in a 15 minute video.

Our team picked the problem to be solved is food waste problem and we make a video on how we can convert food waste into plastic bags :( If your team have free-riders then congrats, you are f*cked. [More on this in the workload section]

===Final Exam===
The final exam is SO F*CKING DIFFICULT! You got 3 hours to complete 10 MC and 4 LQ.

For the MC, they ask the smallest details in the lecture notes like the use of water in producing corn syrup :( They also ask about which topics are not covered in the guest speaker lectures... Now I regret falling asleep in that talk :P

For the LQ, first question asks about the themes of project-winning teams. Just write the themes down in your notes. Next, you got 1 question for every module (So total you have 3 questions). Each of them are so painfully difficult that will make you question why you enrolled this course in the first place. The question types are completely new and it's a disaster (Much difficult than the sample final papers given to you)

I'm generally surprised to get 78.5 marks in the final to be honest. Also the mean of the final exam is low :(
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is so freaking high when compared to other Year 1 courses. Professor Chau loves to annoy and torture you with different methods!

===Homework Workload===
Basically you need to submit one homework for nearly EACH lesson. Sometimes you need to submit a short paragraph describing the chemical engineering stuff you felt 'interested' and sometimes you do calculations.

The most frustrating about the homework is that the calculation problems are missing SO MANY important information. Especially for the diffusion problems,there's no way you calculate anything as you need to freaking ASSUME values for some constants in the equation. How the hell am I supposed to know that?

===Project Workload===
The project is so frustrating. The TAs demand you to create a new stupid Instagram account to post your photos during meetings with your teammates so that they can give you participation marks. You need to fake photos and post them regularly after there's a weekly tutorial session (The tutorial is for you to discuss with your teammates). The whole Instagram thing has turn into a place for spamming photos and competition of which team is the most active.

At the end, you need to hand in 15-minute long video featuring background information, your chemical process and the pros and cons of this process. If you want to get higher marks then you need to animate your stupid video using Powtoon and also edit your video.

===Studying Workload===
The studying workload mainly comes from drilling questions from the 6 mock final papers given to you at the very beginning. It's frustrating to get the questions wrong all the time :(

reviews.author: ShayA
reviews.title: Broad content but high workload and useless material
reviews.comment_content: The content is mostly great. It is broad and covers three main areas of chemical engineering that you'll encounter further in the program. There is a good amount of detail into the material which gives students a better idea of how the the field works. However, my gripe is mainly with the excess amount of extra content in this course. In the beginning of the chapter there was too much detail about real world examples relating to the chapters. There are also guest lectures which are annoying and frankly, not worth all the time. In retrospect, while I did get a better idea of the field, I feel like the course could better handle different parts of the content.
reviews.comment_teaching: Ying Chau is an excellent and attentive teacher. The negative reviews on this site are, in my opinion, a reflection of the content, structure or the workload in this course rather than Chau's teaching itself. She has a good command over the materials and is able to communicate her ideas very effectively. Her accent is good and overall, she is a fun instructor to learn from.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is divided up into quizzes, a group project, IPRS, homework and a final. The final was 40% of the grade which is fair enough. The mean, however, was laughable (a 46/100 I think). I'm not sure if this is a reflection of the student's efforts or the content difficulty. The questions are undoubtedly hard and seem way harder than what could be expected by just being in class. The quizzes were a similar story but just with annoyingly less time. The thing is, the questions are structured to be long questions which take time to understand and solve. It takes a long time just to get a gist of the question and when you realize you made an error, it is too difficult to backtrack and review your long answer. Time management is what makes it way more difficult.The mean for the quizzes was roughly 6/10 and they were taken at times when students were definitely not ready. The project is was a sad display from start to finish. It was difficult to get my partners to get started but that did not matter because it felt like the whole thing was a video editing competition and none of us knew anything about making videos. My team and I got below mean in the project so I might just be talking out of spite, but that's my verdict (Death to all group projects). The project was 30% (hurt my grade immensely) and the quizzes were 15%. The IPRS and homework comprised the rest but did not make much of a dent. I managed to get just above average in the homework, quizzes and the IPRS (with a decent amount of effort), waaaaaay above average in the final (not boasting, just trying to emphasize how low the mean was but I did make a good amount of effort and and i still owe some of it to my pre-existing skill in chemistry), and my project was below average. Overall, I managed to get an A which is not extremely difficult as long as you make sure you get a good grasp of the topic AS YOU GO RATHER THAN AT THE END LIKE AN IDIOT ( me actually, that idiot is me). As for the project, manage your team and choose good team mates, you'll be fine.
reviews.comment_workload: Unbearable for one course. Two weekly homework on top of IPRS every class was horribly annoying.The homework take too much time and you spend all night just coming up with the weirdest solutions to what were supposed to be simple practice questions. Quizzes every month were also a pain. In the later half of the course, working for the project was an extra annoyance. I kid you not, we had the project deadline, a quiz and a god damn homework due in one week. Insane amount of work in my opinion. Manageable but will take up a lot of time if you are serious about the course.

reviews.author: dlo00
reviews.comment_content:
You learn materials balance, energy balance, and finally some kinematics and drug delivery. For each unit you have a short 20-minute quiz in which you have to do calculations - some of which you'll need a calculus background to understand. I know there are people who got full marks on quizzes, but personally the time allocated for the quiz wasn't enough for me to do calculations.
The materials balance quiz is the easiest unit, and from then on it goes downhill. The final exam was really hard. However, I found the content of the last unit really interesting. As well, the calculations are fun to do, even if they are hard.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Chau is very passionate about both chemical/biological engineering and teaching. She knows by name the students who participate in class and will stay behind to explain concepts in a different way if you do not understand the first time. Her lectures and slides are organised and easy to follow, though sometimes she doesn't finish all the slides in one lecture and has to leave them till the next.
Usually she goes through slides and explains things, and then gives students some time to do an example question. I suggest that you go through the slides before class and attempt the questions first, as you won't have much time to do so within the short time frame she gives.
Sometimes she likes to spice things up by bringing some objects or having students come up and demonstrate theories of kinematics. She also invites PG students, professors, and alumni to come and share their experiences as chemical engineers.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading was fair. You will need to put in time studying to get a good grade.
The prof uses IPRS for attendance; other than the final exam, you also have a project and three quizzes.
reviews.comment_workload:
You are usually given a calculation or brief research-based question each lecture. You will need to think quite hard for the calculation-based questions, but luckily you are only given one or two at a time.
Just doing the homework won't be enough to get a good grade. You should also study by reviewing old questions and  doing other questions in thermodynamics textbooks.
There is also a group project in groups of five. Two of my groupmates were complete freeriders but luckily we managed to pull through and be voted one of the top projects. We presented the video in class and answered one or two questions, so the presentation wasn't too hard, and you don't have to prepare for it as long as you know what's going on in the project.

reviews.author: whoooami
reviews.title: Heavy Workload, but not too difficult
reviews.comment_content:
Module 1. Food/Chemical Industry and Material Balance
Mainly using High Fructose Corn Syrup (HFCS) production as issue, introducing the concept of material balance. Easy if you know mole concepts well. Just remember In-Out+Reaction=Accumulation is fine.

Module 2. Energy Balance and Energy Industry
First Law of Thermodynamics will be the mathematical tools in this module. Then, concept of enthalpy change will be introduced, very similar to heat and gases learnt in HKDSE Physics syllabus.

Module 3. Pharmaceutical industry, transport and kinetics
Some basic exponential calculation. Watch out if you do not have "common sense" in biology.

Extra: Many guests talks, mainly about the industry and career future of Chemical and Biological Engineers. Very useful and insightful if you are interested in joining CBE.
